did.unittitle: Sally Lusk papers 1975-2001
did.abstract: Sally Lusk was a professor of nursing at the University of Michigan from 1969 to 2003. She was very involved in the field of occupational health nursing, and focused her research on the effects of noise on workers, as well as how to integrate nursing research into practice. The collection mainly consists of conference presentations, papers, and grant projects related to her research.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: This collection (donor no. 9218) was received in June and August, 2002.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open without restriction.

userestrict.p: Copyright is held by the Regents of the University of Michigan.

prefercite.p: [item], folder, box, Sally Lusk Papers, 1975-2001, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: Sally Clark Lechlitner Lusk, PhD, RN, FAAN, graduated from Memorial Hospital School of Nursing in 1961, and received her Bachelor of Science in Nursing from Indiana University in 1967. She received a Masters of Public Health from the University of Michigan in 1969, and a PhD of Educational Psychology from the University of Michigan in 1979. She is mainly involved with the field of occupational health nursing.

Sally Lusk worked as a nurse in various locations from 1961 to 1968 before becoming an instructor at the University of Michigan School of Nursing in 1969. She became an Association Professor of Nursing, with tenure, in July 1973, and Professor of Nursing in September 1995. She also became Director of Occupational Health Nursing in 1987.

Lusk's main research interests are the role of nurses and the effect of noise. She has conducting many studies on noise-induced hearing loss in factory and construction workers, non-auditory effects of the noise, and means to improve the use of hearing protection among workers. Lusk has also been involved in studying the role of occupational health nurses in the corporate and industrial environments, how nurses can use nursing research to improve their practice, and on protecting health care workers from blood-born pathogens.

In addition to her research, Sally Lusk has been instrumental in improving nursing education in Michigan. In the late 1970's, she headed an effort to design a community-based Bachelor of Science in Nursing program for registered nurses. Programs were established at three off-campus locations to allow nurses to continue their education while working. She was also involved in starting the Masters in Occupational Health Nursing at the University of Michigan, improving University of Michigan Nursing curriculum, and establishing an on-campus masters program in occupational health nursing for working nurses.
For additional information, see her website at http://www-personal.umich.edu/~lusk/

scopecontent.p: This collection is divided into 5 series: Personal, Conference Presentations, Grant Projects, Publications and Other Activities.

Acronyms frequently used in this collection:
AAOHN -- American Association of Occupational Health Nurses
AHCPR -- Agency for Health Care Policy and Research
APHA -- American Public Health Association
BSN -- Bachelor of Science in Nursing
COHSE -- Center for Occupational Health and Safety Engineering, (University of Michigan)
HEMA -- Health Education Media Association
MNRS -- Midwest Nursing Research Society

controlaccess.head: Subjects:
controlaccess.corpname: American Association of Occupational Health Nurses.
Agency for Health Care Policy and Research.

did.unittitle: Personal

scopecontent.p: Personal (0.1 linear feet) contains several curriculum vitae from different points in Lusk's career, as well as a summary of her proposed activities for a sabbatical leave from 1995 to 1996 and a taped interview with Lusk. Social security numbers have been redacted from the CV's.

did.unittitle: Curriculum Vitae
"News Briefs Interview With Sally Lusk," (audio cassette tape) 1993
Sabbatical Leave 1995-1996
Conference Presentations 1988-1997

scopecontent.p: Conference Presentations (1.25 linear feet, 1988-1997) includes abstracts, presentation slides, notes, handouts, and summaries of data from presentations given by Sally Lusk. The main topics covered are the effects of noise on factory workers, using nursing research to improve nursing practice, and the role of occupational health nurses. There is also a list of presentations given by Sally Lusk from 1976-1997. The papers are arranged in reverse-chronological order.

Grant Projects 1974-2000

scopecontent.p: Grant Projects (1.75 linear feet, 1974-2000) is composed of papers related to several grant projects that Sally Lusk directed. Most of the papers are from starting a community-based Bachelor of Science in Nursing program for registered nurses in the 1970s. Papers include grant applications, progress reports, and workbooks developed for the program. The other grant projects are from the 1990s and include developing an interactive computer program to educate workers on the use of hearing protection, studies on worker hearing loss, and establishing an on-campus masters program in occupational health nursing for working nurses. The papers are arranged alphabetically by grant. Social security numbers have been redacted from the grant applications.

Publications 1988-1997

scopecontent.p: Publications (0.25 linear feet, 1988-1997) contains copies of articles published by Sally Lusk, mostly on the role of nurses and the effects of noise on workers. Many of the articles are from a series she wrote for the American Association of Occupation Health Nurses Journal entitled "Linking Practice and Research." A few articles also include notes from peer reviews. The articles are arranged in reverse-chronological order.

Other Activities

scopecontent.p: Other Activities (0.25 linear feet) are papers from organizations Lusk was involved in related to nursing. These include the Agency for Health Care Policy and Research (AHCPR) Nurse Scholar Program and Workers Health Expert Meetings (1998-2000), the Health Education Media Association (HEMA) Board (1976-1979), and curriculum development for the University of Michigan Nursing Program (1998).
